msItem.title: Testamenta duodecim patriarcharum
msItem.rubric: Incipit testamenta duodecim patriarcharum In quibus apertissime atque pulcherrrime de Christo prophetie quesumus nuper transtulit magister Robertus grossum caput Lincolnensis episcopus de latino in grecum. Transcriptum testamenti Ruben.
msItem.incipit: Transcriptum testamenti Ruben quecumque mandavit filiis suis antequam moreretur in centesimo vicesimo quinto vite sue anno
msItem.explicit: Et habitaverunt in Egipto usque ad diem exitus eorum ex terra Egipti.

msItem.title: History of Joseph and Asenath
msItem.rubric: Quanto desiderio viri flagrabant in Asseneth virginem virginem
msItem.incipit: In illo tempore erat Ioseph in finibus Eleopoleos missus a Pharaone
msItem.explicit: Et interfecisset eos nisi Asseneth pro eis intercesserat.
msItem.note: In his notes on the flyleaves Bliss refers to correspondence with Robert Curzon, who discussed the Book of Asenath (a different, longer, text) in his Armenia: A year at Erzeroom … (London, 1854), p. 204.

msItem.author: Richard de Bury
msItem.title: Philobiblon
msItem.rubric: Incipit philobliblon id est tracatatus de amore librorum venerabilis viri domini Richardi de Buri episcopi Dunelmensis editus et per venerabilem magistrum Robertum Holkot anglicum ordinis predicatorum
msItem.incipit: Universis Christi fidelibus ad quos presentis scripture tenor pervenerit
msItem.explicit: ad suum reducat primordiale prototypum ac eiusdem concedat perpetuum fruibilis faciei conspectum. Per dominum nostrum Amen.
msItem.bibl: Ed. A. Altamura (Naples, 1954), citing the present MS. at pp. 10, 30, 142 (siglum ‘Bd’).
msItem.note: This manuscript and its text are discussed by Andrew Fleming West, The Philobiblon of Richard de Bury, iii (New York, 1889), pp. 84–86.

msItem.title: Two short extracts relating to the care of books

msItem.incipit: Libros quippe tamquam sempiternum animarum cibum cautissime custodiri
msItem.explicit: vel ad desiderium fuerint patrie celestis accensi.
msItem.bibl: ed. [M. Laporte], Guiges Ier, Coutumes de Chartreuse: Introduction, texte critique et notes, Sources Chrétiennes, 313 (Paris, 1984), p. 224 (cap. 28.3–4).

msItem.author: Ps.-Bonaventura
msItem.title: Speculum discipline ad nouitios
msItem.bibl: pars II, cap. IV: De rerum custodia
msItem.rubric: Ex libro qui dicitur Speculum discipline
msItem.incipit: Res quas tenent pprecipue libros munde teneant et honeste
msItem.explicit: qui mundicia gaudet et honestatis pulchritudine delectatur.

msItem.author: Gregory the Great
msItem.title: Epistolarum Lib. II
msItem.rubric: Beatus Gregorius papa in epistola ad natalem episcopum
msItem.incipit: Convivia autem que ex intencione impendende caritatis fiunt
msItem.explicit: si causa contigerit in nobis esse etiam paciendo monstrare Amen.

msItem.author: Jean Gerson
msItem.title: De laude scriptorum
msItem.rubric: Incipit tracatus magistri Johannis Gerson cancellarii Parisiensis de laude scriptorum ad Carthusienses et Celestinos ymmo totam ecclesiam constitutus
msItem.incipit: Scrutari scripturas exhortabatur olim Judeos Christus Jo. V [cf. John 5:39]. Scripturas videlicet in quibus putabant se vitam eternam habere
msItem.explicit: liber vite speciosissimus deus benedictus in secula Amen.
msItem.bibl: ed. Glorieux, Jean Gerson: Œuvres complètes, ix (Paris, 1973), pp. 423–34 no. 454.

msItem.title: Alphabetical glossary
msItem.incipit: Absintheum herba quedam amara et ponitur pro amaritudine
msItem.explicit: Et sic brevissime huic operi imponitur finis benedictus deus.
msItem.note: The first words are Absintheum, Abrogare, Acuratissime, and Agapeta; the last are Ydea, Yle, Yperdulia, and Zelus.
West, op. cit., p. 85–8, states that 244 words are defined, of which about 200 are from the Philobiblon; he cites this unique ‘Oxford Glossary’ at pp. 103, 110, 116.

layoutDesc.layout: Frame-ruled in pale ink for two columns of about 41–43 lines, c. 217 153

binding.p: Bound in brown cloth, matching MS. Add. C. 109 and MS. Add. C. 110, probably for Bliss by David Nutt, of Winchester (see MS. Add. C. 110); the spine stamped in gilt with the shelfmark and ‘MSS | I–II’. The edges of the leaves speckled red.

history.provenance: Edward Lumley (1806–1874), bookseller of Chancery Lane and High Holborn, London.

William Henry Bliss (1835–1911), scholar, priest, convert to Catholicism, Keeper of Periodicals at the Bodleian, and representative of the Public Record Office in the Vatican Archives; with his armorial bookplate (with his shield, crest, name, and motto ‘Quod severis metes’) inscribed in pencil ‘1854.’; his name in pencil (fols. 18r, 20r); an ink stamp with his family crest, a sheaf of wheat, and motto ‘They that sow in tears shall reap in joy’ (fol. i recto); inscribed ‘These MSS, and three others bound up in two volumes similar to this one were purchased of Mr Lumley bookseller, of Holborn; being part of a volume in the original oak & stamped leather binding & which contained a copy of Walter Burley’s Lives of the Philosophers – [printed by] Coburger of Nuremberg 1477’ (fol. i recto; the latter is now Auct 2 Q inf. 2.73); with further notes on the MSS texts on fol. ii r–v and within the volume.
history.acquisition: Purchased from Bliss by the Bodleian, 26 June 1868, for £1 10s 0d.; inscribed ‘purchased in 1868’ (front pastedown). Former Bodleian shelfmarks: ‘MSS. Addit. Bodl. Π. E. 19’ (‘Π. E. 19’ cancelled by encircling and superseded by ‘C. 108’, also encircled).
